an5.30:4.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins called Icchānaṅgala.
an5.30:4.3: He stayed on in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
an5.30:4.4: The brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala heard:
an5.30:4.5: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala.
an5.30:4.6: He is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
an5.30:4.8: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an5.30:4.9: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
an5.30:4.10: He teaches Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an5.30:4.11: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
an5.30:4.12: Then, when the night had passed, they took many different foods and went to the forest near Icchānaṅgala,
an5.30:4.13: where they stood outside the gates making a dreadful racket.
an5.30:5.1: Now, at that time Venerable Nāgita was the Buddha’s attendant.
an5.30:5.2: Then the Buddha said to Nāgita:
an5.30:5.3: “Nāgita, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
an5.30:5.4: “Sir, it’s these brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala. They’ve brought many different foods, and they’re standing outside the gates wanting to offer it specially to the Buddha and the mendicant Saṅgha.”
an5.30:5.5: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
an5.30:5.6: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.
an5.30:5.7: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.”
an5.30:6.1: “Sir, may the Blessed One please relent now! May the Holy One relent!
an5.30:6.2: Now is the time for the Buddha to relent.
an5.30:6.3: Wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
an5.30:6.4: It’s like when it rains heavily and the water flows downhill.
an5.30:6.5: In the same way, wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
an5.30:6.7: Because of the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.”
an5.30:7.1: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
an5.30:7.2: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.
an5.30:7.3: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.
an5.30:7.4: What you eat, drink, chew, and taste ends up as excrement and urine.
an5.30:7.6: When loved ones decay and perish, sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress arise.
an5.30:7.8: When you’re committed to meditating on the aspect of ugliness, you becomes firmly put off by aspect of beauty.
an5.30:7.10: When you meditate observing impermanence in the six fields of contact, repulsion at contact becomes firm.
an5.30:7.12: When you meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates, repulsion at grasping becomes firm.
